title: What are the general rules of politics? - Quora

response.answer_text: These are rules I live by when it comes to researching anything on politics. Never use a source beyond a left or right center bias. The only exceptions to this rule is for the sake of showing multiple arguments of differing views, or for showing something out of normal. For example, let’s say a left leaning source supports gun rights. If you are arguing for gun rights, and you argue “even this usually left leaning source agrees with me on this”, it is acceptable. Never use a new source for the primary source. Not unless you just need a quick, yet accurate and trustworthy source of statistics. Even then, see if you can find a better, more trustworthy source. Always be on the look out for trustworthy sources you can use. For example, when I talk about economic issues, I like to use investopedia, and the balance for good facts, that have little to no political motivation. I also use pew research, and http://usnews.com sometimes. Gallup Research is also trustworthy. Be sure you find sources that you know are trustworthy. If you think the source is politically motivated, displays irrelevant information, or does not enough, do not use that source at all. When you all of that, then you may form a political opinion. If you can’t back up what you are saying in any way, then don’t espouse it. Be willing to admit when you are wrong. Don’t ignore the opposing view point of they provide a statistic or a source. Instead, review it and come to your own conclusion. If they fail to back up what they are saying by using logic, a source of some kind, or the source provides irrelevant information and is not backed by logic, the argument fails. Become as unemotional as possible. While I don’t entirely agree with the “loss your cool, lose the argument” concept, it will hurt your credibility, as well as degrade your argument much faster. Be on the look out for fallacies they might provide in their argument to degrade their argument further. Even though fallacies are pretty much unavoidable to a degree, you can at least limit yourself by trying to not do too many of them yourself, and pointing them out when you see them. Keep your bias to yourself. Conceive that you might be wrong. If not saying you should think you are always wrong, but keep that possibility in mind. That’s about what I do. I might be missing a few thing. :)

Make sure the best interests of your country are being served. But make sure you are not too ruthless and autocratic or your voters might stop voting for you. That is if you live in a democracy. When a political leader operates outside a democratic system there is only one rule. Hang on to your power.
If there aint any create a controversy. If there is one , ride it like a horse. If people are cool with each other, find something to rile them up. If people are riled up, ride it like a horse.
